p: O. europaea is known to contain a wide range of phytochemical components with medicinal properties from as far back as 1854 and a number of phytochemical components have been isolated from different parts of O. europaea. The bark, fruits, seeds, leaves, olive oil and wood contain phenolic compounds, flavonoids and secoridoids. Due to the presence of many compounds in different parts of the plant, it has an array of uses including control of plasma concentrations of glucose, cholesterol and urate [ 9].
